data.name: IK - Inverse Kinematics (2D)
data.description:
You are asked to solve the inverse kinematics prolem.


given a set of bones like [1,2,3] and an end position: (3,1),
determine a correct set of angles on the joints (global angles)
=[a1,a2,a3]

so that (a1,1)+(a2,2)+(a3,3)=(3,1) where the former are polar coordinates.

so adding up the bone lengths with their angles should arrive near the specified position. your first bone is always anchored at (0,0)

all solutions that place the end part of the last bone within the distance of the goal are valid. (being near the goal := within 0.5 units)

some users sought to cheat by reassigning some functions i wrote.
i'll try to check for that.

goal is encoded as (x,y) and angles are in radians relative
to (1,0)

------------------------------------
i've found you can start with cyclic coordinate descent, simplified: you just adjust things along
the kinematic chain iteratively.
--------------------------------------
a future hard version might be the 3d version, complete with more restrictions on the joint angles
